Description: Piece of limestone which has been crudely carved, possibly intended to represent a human figure. This fragment of soft limestone has been worked into a stylised shape with rough indications of a head, arms, and legs. The head area has an additional semi-circular shaped layer of limestone, and the area directly underneath has a raised ridge – possibly intended to represent the face of the figure. There are visible traces of black paint across the surface on both sides. The figure has a large chip to the left leg on the reverse, and numerous further abrasions across the surface of the reverse. There are also visible chips to the ‘chest’ area of the figure and at the arms and legs.
Curator's comments: Crudely carved limestone figures such as this example have been interpreted as possible ‘captive’ figures (Thomas 2015). These are relatively rare at Naukratis and highly variable in form, with a selection of other prisoner figures now held in various collections (see list in Thomas 2015). ‘Rude stone figures’ were recognised by Petrie to be a local, early production, dating to the 6th – 4th centuries BC (Petrie 1886); these have since been dated more specifically to c. 620 – 400 BC (Thomas 2015, also provides a further list of comparable examples from sites including Saqqara, Tell Dafana, and Herakleion). A possible female prisoner figure from Naukratis made from terracotta is now held in the Museum of Classical Archaeology (Cambridge, NA494). The provenance for this figure is recorded as the sanctuary of Apollo at Naukratis alongside two other votive objects also within the British Museum collection (EA 68823 (1886,0401.1489) and EA 68825 (1886,0401.1492)), however it’s also noted that the location of these finds may be the result of a later ‘disturbed context’ (Thomas 2015). Other possible captive figures from other contexts at Naukratis are included in the British Museum collection (such as EA 68820 (1886,0401.1485) and 2011, 2011.7). Further Bibliography: R.I. Thomas, 2015. ‘Naukratis: Egyptian Late Period figures in terracotta and limestone’, in A. Villing et al (eds.) Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (London), p. 12, n.72, p. 27, n.261, p. 75, n.823. General Sources: S. Heinz, forthcoming. ‘Statuettes, amulets, and the community at Thonis-Heracleion’, in R. Thomas (ed.) Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011. W.M.F. Petrie, 1886. Naukratis. Part I., 1884–5 (third memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (CE.161)
Acquisition name: Donated by: Egypt Exploration Fund (Committee of)
